abstract.text: A Uniform Resource Locator (URL) is a universal identifier,
which often describes the location of a resource.

inlineContent.text: A Uniform Resource Locator (URL) is a universal identifier, which often describes the location of a resource.
Construct a
by calling
with a URL String:
aligns with the
, which which governs how browsers and other
actors on the web platform should interpret URLs. To demonstrate, the following example includes a number of
syntax mistakes: leading spaces, a mixed-case scheme and domain name, incorrect number of leading slashes,
as well as unescaped internal spaces and Unicode characters. These sorts of mistakes are relatively common
not only in user input, but also in network responses and databases. Browsers and JavaScript are able to
interpret these, and supporting them is important for true compatibility with the web.
An important feature of the standard is that URLs are always normalized, so when constructing a
the URL is automatically cleaned up and made easier for other systems and libraries to work with.
To see this in action, letâ€™s obtain the URLâ€™s string representation by calling the
function.

code: let url = WebURL("  HTtpS:///MYAPP.COM/sendMessage?I saw a ðŸ¦†!")!

inlineContent.text: URLs are made up of a series of components, such as their
, and
You can read and write a URL componentâ€™s string value using its respective property.
WebURL is always normalized, so modified components will be normalized automatically.
Whilst it may be familiar to work with URL components as strings, they do not fully capture everything that
knows about a particular component, and require navigating percent-encoding, which can be difficult.
For some components which have additional formal/informal meaning, WebURL offers richer APIs which
are both more precise and more convenient than operating on string values directly:
The
property returns the URLâ€™s hostname as an enum.
This allows request libraries to understand hostnames as the URL parser does, and to directly establish
a network connection.
The
property returns a
view of a URLâ€™s path,
and can even be used to add and remove path components.
(Demonstrated below)
The
property returns a view of a URLâ€™s query as a sequence of form-encoded key-value pairs,
and offers dynamic properties to read and write query parameters.
(Demonstrated below)
The
property is a mutable wrapper which provides a URLâ€™s path components
as a standard Swift
. It supports for-loops, slicing, map/reduce/filter and more,
but also adds methods like
, which efficiently modify the URL in-place.
The
property offers a similar interface for query parameters using form-encoding.
You can read and write the value for a key using the
and
methods, or use Swiftâ€™s dynamic-member syntax to access them
as properties.
In addition to all of the above, WebURL offers integration libraries so it may be used with popular first-party and
third-party libraries.
